          <article id="post-21341" class="post post-21341 type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-adtech category-en category-mobile-marketing">
            <div class="blogpage_content">
            
			<div class="post_title_area left title_position_above"><div class="postcategory_area postcategory_above"><span class="categories-links above box"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210828232159/https://applift.com/blog/category/adtech" rel="category tag">adtech</a> <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210828232159/https://applift.com/blog/category/en" rel="category tag">en</a> <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210828232159/https://applift.com/blog/category/mobile-marketing" rel="category tag">Mobile Marketing</a></span></div><h1 class="entry-title">Applift’s Compendium of Adtech Abbreviation</h1><ul class="entry_meta_list"><li><span class="date updated"><span class="meta_label"></span><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210828232159/https://applift.com/blog/applifts-compendium-of-adtech-abbreviation" title="Permalink to Applift’s Compendium of Adtech Abbreviation" rel="bookmark">April 24, 2020</a></span></li><li><span class="author-list author vcard"><span class="meta_label">By </span><a class="url fn n" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210828232159/https://applift.com/blog/author/applift" title="View all posts by Applift" rel="author">Applift</a></span></li></ul></div>
             
           
                        
                        
                            
                <div class="blog_text_area">
                    <div class="post-content">
                        <div class="entry-content">
                       		<div data-row-text-color="dark" style=" " class="vc_row wpb_row zolo_wpb_row vc_row-fluid apress_row_class_601795850612ac518234da"><div class="wpb_column vc_column_container vc_col-sm-12 apress_col_id_1490358747612ac518250e4 hover_style_none"><div class="layer vc_column-inner "><div class="wpb_wrapper">
	<div class="wpb_text_column wpb_content_element ">
		<div class="wpb_wrapper">
			<p><span style="font-weight: 400">We know that there can be a lot of technical jargon in the world of adtech. Learning to distinguish between CPA, CPI and CPS could be vital to ensuring you implement the ideal advertising strategy. </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400">As a guide for <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210828232159/https://applift.com/blog/a-beginners-guide-to-in-app-advertising">beginners</a> (as well as a helpful reminder for seasoned marketers), we have compiled all of the need-to-know terms, metrics, and stakeholder acronyms in an adtech glossary to position you in the best position moving forward.</span></p>
<p> </p>
<h1 style="text-align: left"><b>Crucial Adtech Acronyms</b></h1>
<p><img loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-medium" src="https://web.archive.org/web/20210828232159im_/https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1583361704493-d4d4d1b1d70a?ixlib=rb-1.2.1&ixid=eyJhcHBfaWQiOjEyMDd9&auto=format&fit=crop&w=1502&q=80" width="1502" height="1001"/></p>
<p><strong>API: (Application Programming Interface) –</strong> <span style="font-weight: 400">The functions and procedures by which a software system or component defines how other software can communicate with it. Without it, Slack could not notify you of upcoming meetings and Facebook’s share button would not exist outside of Facebook. Not to be mistaken with SDK.       </span></p>
<p><b>ASO: (App Store Optimization) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">The process of increasing an app’s visibility and ranking within an app store in order to maximise downloads.           </span></p>
<p><b>CTA: (Call to Action) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">The button users press in order to perform a desirable action such as an install, download, or purchase, e.g. “click here”, “subscribe”, “buy now”.</span></p>
<p><b>DMP: (Data Management Platform) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">A platform where companies can identify audience segments, targeting, and ad campaigns.      </span></p>
<p><b>DSP: (Demand Side Platform) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">A system that allows advertisers to programmatically manage multiple ad and data exchange accounts through a single interface.  </span></p>
<p><b>GAID: (Google Android Unique Identifier)</b> <b>–</b><span style="font-weight: 400"> Google/Android’s unique (but user-resettable) string identifier which allows ad networks and other apps to anonymously identify users.  </span></p>
<p><b>IAP: (In-App Purchases) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">The purchases a user makes inside of an app’s interface, e.g. purchasing an uber ride, a Netflix subscription, or a new character in a mobile game.</span></p>
<p><b>IDFA: (Identifier for Advertisers) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">Apple’s unique but user-resettable string identifier which allows ad networks and other apps to anonymously identify users.</span></p>
<p><b>KPI: (Key Performance Indicator / Performance Indicator) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">A form of performance measurement used to evaluate the success of a campaign. Businesses select their own KPI/s depending on their ultimate campaign goals. As such, KPIs differ greatly from business to business, but for mobile advertising campaigns, some of the most popular include CPA, CPI, and CPV.  </span></p>
<p><b>RTB: (Real Time Bidding) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">The way in which advertising inventory is bought and sold via a programmatic instantaneous auction on a per-impression basis. Not to be mistaken with programmatic advertising (</span><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210828232159/https://www.centro.net/blog/programmatic-vs-rtb-a-common-misconception-in-ad-tech"><span style="font-weight: 400">learn the difference</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400">).</span></p>
<p><b>SDK: (Software Development Kit) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">A package of software tools, programs, and code which developers can add to their app to aid in the measurement of analytics and advertising data.</span></p>
<p><b>SSP: (Supply Side Platform) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">A technology platform which enables web publishers and digital out-of-home media owners to manage their advertising inventory and offer it to the advertisers.</span></p>
<p><b>TL: (Tracking Link) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">A normal URL with tags (parameters) appended to the end, allowing for the tracking of visitors. It is used to measure the effectiveness of marketing campaigns, channels, and activities.</span></p>
<p><b>VTA: (View-through Attribution)</b> <b>–</b><span style="font-weight: 400"> The way in which advertisers attribute installs or actions to impression-based mobile advertising campaigns. Also known as ‘impression tracking’.</span></p>
<p> </p>
<h1 style="text-align: left"><b>Adtech Metrics</b></h1>
<p><img loading="lazy" class="size-medium aligncenter" src="https://web.archive.org/web/20210828232159im_/https://cdn.pixabay.com/photo/2017/09/10/21/10/measure-2737004_1280.jpg" width="1280" height="853"/></p>
<p><b>ARPU:</b> <b>(Average Revenue per User / Average Revenue per Unit) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">A metric used to measure the factors which contribute to overall revenue – helping companies analyze their growth patterns and compare performance with competitors.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Total Revenue </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400"> Number of Users]</span></i></p>
<p><b>ARPPU: (Average Revenue per Paying User) –</b><span style="font-weight: 400"> The average amount of money generated from a paying customer.   [</span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">Monthly Recurring Revenue </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400"> Active Paying Customers]</span></i></p>
<p><b>ARPDAU: (Average Revenue per Daily Active User) –</b><span style="font-weight: 400">  A measure of how much money every regular user generates daily. The revenue earned can be from ads, in-app purchases, subscriptions, or any other monetization model used by the app.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Revenue earned in 24 hours </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷ </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">Number of active users in the same time]</span></i></p>
<p><b>CPA:</b><span style="font-weight: 400"> (</span><b>Cost per Action / Cost per Acquisition) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">An ad KPI and pricing model that accounts for the price an advertiser pays only after a specific action (such as registration or payment) has been performed in the installed app.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Cost to the Advertiser </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400"> Number of Actions, Campaign Conversions] </span></i><span style="font-weight: 400">(</span><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210828232159/https://applift.com/blog/measuring-real-mobile-engagement-requires-cpa"><span style="font-weight: 400">Learn more</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400">)</span></p>
<p><b>eCPA: </b> <b>(effective Cost per Action) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">An ad KPI and pricing calculation that measures the cost it takes to get a new user to perform an action. The main difference between CPA and eCPA is the data used to calculate it: eCPA is a way of calculating CPA for campaigns that did not use CPA as the buying method. In other words, eCPA is a calculation that reveals what CPA would have been if actions had been bought instead of views, installs, etc.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Total Ad Spend </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400"> Total Number of Actions Taken]</span></i></p>
<p><b>CPC: (Cost per Click) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">An ad KPI and pricing model that accounts for the price an advertiser pays for each click on an ad  </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Cost to the Advertiser </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400"> Number of Clicks]</span></i></p>
<p><b>CPI: (Cost per Install) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">An ad KPI and pricing model that accounts for the price an advertiser pays only if an ad click results in an app install.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Cost to the Advertiser </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400"> Number of Installs (directly resulting from the ad campaign)]</span></i></p>
<p><b>eCPI: (effective Cost per Install) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">An ad KPI and pricing model that measures the cost it takes to acquire a new install. Unlike CPI, eCPI factors in organic and viral installs.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Total Ad Spend </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400"> Total Number of Installs]</span></i></p>
<p><b>CPL: (Cost per Lead) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">An ad KPI and pricing model that accounts for the price an advertiser pays for a relevant lead resulting from an ad campaign.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Cost to the Advertiser </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400"> Number of Campaign Leads]</span></i></p>
<p><b>CPM: (Cost per Mille) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">An ad KPI and pricing model that accounts for the price an advertiser pays for one thousand views of an ad.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Cost to the Advertiser </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400"> Number of Campaign Impressions </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">×</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400"> 1000]</span></i></p>
<p><b>eCPM: (effective Cost per Mille) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">An ad KPI and pricing calculation that measures the ad revenue generated per 1000 ad impressions. The main difference between CPM and eCPM is the data used to calculate it: eCPM is a way of calculating CPM for campaigns that did not use CPM as the buying method. In other words, eCPM is a calculation that reveals what CPM would have been if impressions had been bought instead of actions, installs, etc.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Total Earnings from an Ad </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400"> Total Impressions </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">×</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400"> 1000]</span></i></p>
<p><b>CPO: (Cost per Order / Cost per Purchase) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">An ad KPI and pricing model that accounts for the price an advertiser pays for a successful order resulting from an ad campaign.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Cost to the Advertiser </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400"> Number of Campaign Orders]</span></i></p>
<p><b>CPS: (Cost per Subscription) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">CPA specific for subscription services, where the action is defined as subscription of a user.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Cost to the Advertiser </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400"> Number of Campaign Subscriptions]</span></i></p>
<p><b>CPR: (Cost per Registration) –</b> <span style="font-weight: 400">An ad KPI and pricing model that measures success based on the generation of new registrations.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Cost to the Advertiser </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷ Number of Resulting Registrations]</span></i></p>
<p><b>CPV: (Cost per View / Cost per Visit) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">Ad KPI and pricing model that accounts for the price an advertiser pays for interaction with the ad (e.g. click, play, expand). Particularly useful for campaigns utilising playable ads.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Cost to the Advertiser </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400"> Number of Campaign Views]</span></i></p>
<p><b>CR / CCR (Churn Rate / Customer Churn Rate) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">The percentage of users whose business is lost (measured via inactivity or unsubscribes) during a given time period (i.e. the rate of attrition). The inverse of Retention Rate.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Number of Lost Customers </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷ Total Number of Customers]</span></i></p>
<p><b>CR / CVR: (Conversion Rate) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">The percentage of users who take a desired action after being exposed to an ad.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Positive Conversions </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400"> Clicks Received </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">×</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400"> 100]</span></i></p>
<p><b>CTIT: (Click to Install Time) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">A type of distribution modelling used to analyze the ‘lag’ interval time-period between a click and its corresponding install. Useful for fraud detection.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Installation Time – Ad Click Time]</span></i></p>
<p><b>CTR: (Click Through Rate) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">The ratio of users who click on an advertised link to the users who view the page or app that has published the link.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Total Ad Clicks </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400"> Total Ad Impressions]</span></i></p>
<p><b>DAU: (Daily Active Users) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">The number of users that interact with an app over the course of 24 hours.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Sum Total of Unique Viewers on a Given Day]</span></i></p>
<p><b>FTD: (First Time Deposit Conversion) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">An acquisition model that is commonly used in the online gambling industry in order to measure conversion rates.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Total Number of Unique Visitors </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷ Number of </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">First Time Deposits]</span></i></p>
<p><b>K: (K-Factor) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">A calculation for measuring the growth rate and virality of websites and apps. It can be simplified as invitations multiplied by conversions.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Number of Invites Sent per Customer </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">× </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">Percentage of Conversions per Invite]</span></i> <b>  </b></p>
<p><b>LTV / CLV: (Lifetime Value / Customer Lifetime Value) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">The predicted net profit attributed to the entire future relationship with a single customer. There are multiple ways to calculate LTV, but simply put, it is customer value multiplied by average customer lifespan.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[ARPU x (1 ÷ Churn Rate)]</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400"> (</span><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210828232159/https://applift.com/blog/ltv-reporting"><span style="font-weight: 400">Learn more</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400">)</span></p>
<p><b>MAU: (Monthly Active Users) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">The number of users that interact with an app over the course of a given month.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Sum Total of Unique Viewers on a Given Month]</span></i></p>
<p><b>RR: (Retention Rate) –</b><span style="font-weight: 400"> The percentage of users who continue using an app over a given time period. The inverse of Churn Rate / Rate of Attrition.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[</span></i><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210828232159/https://applift.com/blog/user-retention"><i><span style="font-weight: 400">See here for calculation models</span></i></a><i><span style="font-weight: 400">]</span></i></p>
<p><b>ROAS: (Return on Ad Spend) –</b><span style="font-weight: 400"> A metric used to calculate the efficacy of an advertising campaign. It is the amount of revenue a company receives for every dollar spent on an advertising source.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[Revenue </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400"> Cost]</span></i></p>
<p><b>ROI: (Return on Investment) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">The ratio of net profit to cost of investment; in other words, the pay-off for ad spend in user acquisition profits.   </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400">[(Total Ad Revenue – Total Ad Campaign Cost) </span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400">÷</span></i><i><span style="font-weight: 400"> Total Ad Campaign Cost]</span></i></p>
<p> </p>
<h1 style="text-align: left"><b>Stakeholders</b></h1>
<p><img loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-medium" src="https://web.archive.org/web/20210828232159im_/https://cdn.pixabay.com/photo/2015/03/26/09/41/tie-690084_1280.jpg" width="1280" height="854"/></p>
<p><b>ADN: (Ad Network) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">A brokerage platform that connects publishers with advertisers.           </span></p>
<p><b>AFN: (Affiliate Network) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">An intermediary between publishers and merchant affiliate programs. Affiliate networks often manage tracking, reporting, and payment on behalf of affiliates. </span></p>
<p><b>DSP: (Demand Side Platform) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">A technology platform that advertisers use to automate the buying of ad space and the monitoring of campaigns.     </span></p>
<p><b>MB: (Media Buyer) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">An individual or team responsible for the placements and price negotiation of advertisements.       </span></p>
<p><b>MMA: (Mobile Marketing Association) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">An industry group that seeks to advance mobile marketing practices and technologies on a global level.    </span></p>
<p><b>MMP: (Mobile Measurement Partner / Attribution Partner) – </b><span style="font-weight: 400">A platform that provides deeper insights into mobile performance metrics through the collection, organization and standardization of app data.</span></p>
<p><b>MP: (Media Partner)</b> <b>–</b><span style="font-weight: 400"> A media outlet or publisher connected to apps with advertising inventory.</span></p>
<p><b>PMP: (Private Marketplace) –</b><span style="font-weight: 400"> An invite-only real-time marketplace where high-calibur publishers can offer their inventories to a select collection of reputable advertisers.</span></p>

		</div>
	</div>
</div></div></div></div>

readabilityObject.title: Applift’s Compendium of Adtech Abbreviation
readabilityObject.content:
We know that there can be a lot of technical jargon in the world of adtech. Learning to distinguish between CPA, CPI and CPS could be vital to ensuring you implement the ideal advertising strategy. 

As a guide for beginners (as well as a helpful reminder for seasoned marketers), we have compiled all of the need-to-know terms, metrics, and stakeholder acronyms in an adtech glossary to position you in the best position moving forward.

Crucial Adtech Acronyms

API: (Application Programming Interface) – The functions and procedures by which a software system or component defines how other software can communicate with it. Without it, Slack could not notify you of upcoming meetings and Facebook’s share button would not exist outside of Facebook. Not to be mistaken with SDK.       

ASO: (App Store Optimization) – The process of increasing an app’s visibility and ranking within an app store in order to maximise downloads.          

CTA: (Call to Action) – The button users press in order to perform a desirable action such as an install, download, or purchase, e.g. “click here”, “subscribe”, “buy now”.

DMP: (Data Management Platform) – A platform where companies can identify audience segments, targeting, and ad campaigns.     

DSP: (Demand Side Platform) – A system that allows advertisers to programmatically manage multiple ad and data exchange accounts through a single interface.  

GAID: (Google Android Unique Identifier) – Google/Android’s unique (but user-resettable) string identifier which allows ad networks and other apps to anonymously identify users. 

IAP: (In-App Purchases) – The purchases a user makes inside of an app’s interface, e.g. purchasing an uber ride, a Netflix subscription, or a new character in a mobile game.

IDFA: (Identifier for Advertisers) – Apple’s unique but user-resettable string identifier which allows ad networks and other apps to anonymously identify users.

KPI: (Key Performance Indicator / Performance Indicator) – A form of performance measurement used to evaluate the success of a campaign. Businesses select their own KPI/s depending on their ultimate campaign goals. As such, KPIs differ greatly from business to business, but for mobile advertising campaigns, some of the most popular include CPA, CPI, and CPV.  

RTB: (Real Time Bidding) – The way in which advertising inventory is bought and sold via a programmatic instantaneous auction on a per-impression basis. Not to be mistaken with programmatic advertising (learn the difference).

SDK: (Software Development Kit) – A package of software tools, programs, and code which developers can add to their app to aid in the measurement of analytics and advertising data.

SSP: (Supply Side Platform) – A technology platform which enables web publishers and digital out-of-home media owners to manage their advertising inventory and offer it to the advertisers.

TL: (Tracking Link) – A normal URL with tags (parameters) appended to the end, allowing for the tracking of visitors. It is used to measure the effectiveness of marketing campaigns, channels, and activities.

VTA: (View-through Attribution) – The way in which advertisers attribute installs or actions to impression-based mobile advertising campaigns. Also known as ‘impression tracking’.

Adtech Metrics

ARPU: (Average Revenue per User / Average Revenue per Unit) – A metric used to measure the factors which contribute to overall revenue – helping companies analyze their growth patterns and compare performance with competitors.   [Total Revenue ÷ Number of Users]

ARPPU: (Average Revenue per Paying User) – The average amount of money generated from a paying customer.   [Monthly Recurring Revenue ÷ Active Paying Customers]

ARPDAU: (Average Revenue per Daily Active User) –  A measure of how much money every regular user generates daily. The revenue earned can be from ads, in-app purchases, subscriptions, or any other monetization model used by the app.   [Revenue earned in 24 hours ÷ Number of active users in the same time]

CPA: (Cost per Action / Cost per Acquisition) – An ad KPI and pricing model that accounts for the price an advertiser pays only after a specific action (such as registration or payment) has been performed in the installed app.   [Cost to the Advertiser ÷ Number of Actions, Campaign Conversions] (Learn more)

eCPA: (effective Cost per Action) – An ad KPI and pricing calculation that measures the cost it takes to get a new user to perform an action. The main difference between CPA and eCPA is the data used to calculate it: eCPA is a way of calculating CPA for campaigns that did not use CPA as the buying method. In other words, eCPA is a calculation that reveals what CPA would have been if actions had been bought instead of views, installs, etc.   [Total Ad Spend ÷ Total Number of Actions Taken]

CPC: (Cost per Click) – An ad KPI and pricing model that accounts for the price an advertiser pays for each click on an ad  [Cost to the Advertiser ÷ Number of Clicks]

CPI: (Cost per Install) – An ad KPI and pricing model that accounts for the price an advertiser pays only if an ad click results in an app install.   [Cost to the Advertiser ÷ Number of Installs (directly resulting from the ad campaign)]

eCPI: (effective Cost per Install) – An ad KPI and pricing model that measures the cost it takes to acquire a new install. Unlike CPI, eCPI factors in organic and viral installs.   [Total Ad Spend ÷ Total Number of Installs]

CPL: (Cost per Lead) – An ad KPI and pricing model that accounts for the price an advertiser pays for a relevant lead resulting from an ad campaign.   [Cost to the Advertiser ÷ Number of Campaign Leads]

CPM: (Cost per Mille) – An ad KPI and pricing model that accounts for the price an advertiser pays for one thousand views of an ad.   [Cost to the Advertiser ÷ Number of Campaign Impressions × 1000]

eCPM: (effective Cost per Mille) – An ad KPI and pricing calculation that measures the ad revenue generated per 1000 ad impressions. The main difference between CPM and eCPM is the data used to calculate it: eCPM is a way of calculating CPM for campaigns that did not use CPM as the buying method. In other words, eCPM is a calculation that reveals what CPM would have been if impressions had been bought instead of actions, installs, etc.   [Total Earnings from an Ad ÷ Total Impressions × 1000]

CPO: (Cost per Order / Cost per Purchase) – An ad KPI and pricing model that accounts for the price an advertiser pays for a successful order resulting from an ad campaign.   [Cost to the Advertiser ÷ Number of Campaign Orders]

CPS: (Cost per Subscription) – CPA specific for subscription services, where the action is defined as subscription of a user.   [Cost to the Advertiser ÷ Number of Campaign Subscriptions]

CPR: (Cost per Registration) – An ad KPI and pricing model that measures success based on the generation of new registrations.   [Cost to the Advertiser ÷ Number of Resulting Registrations]

CPV: (Cost per View / Cost per Visit) – Ad KPI and pricing model that accounts for the price an advertiser pays for interaction with the ad (e.g. click, play, expand). Particularly useful for campaigns utilising playable ads.   [Cost to the Advertiser ÷ Number of Campaign Views]

CR / CCR (Churn Rate / Customer Churn Rate) – The percentage of users whose business is lost (measured via inactivity or unsubscribes) during a given time period (i.e. the rate of attrition). The inverse of Retention Rate.   [Number of Lost Customers ÷ Total Number of Customers]

CR / CVR: (Conversion Rate) – The percentage of users who take a desired action after being exposed to an ad.   [Positive Conversions ÷ Clicks Received × 100]

CTIT: (Click to Install Time) – A type of distribution modelling used to analyze the ‘lag’ interval time-period between a click and its corresponding install. Useful for fraud detection.   [Installation Time – Ad Click Time]

CTR: (Click Through Rate) – The ratio of users who click on an advertised link to the users who view the page or app that has published the link.   [Total Ad Clicks ÷ Total Ad Impressions]

DAU: (Daily Active Users) – The number of users that interact with an app over the course of 24 hours.   [Sum Total of Unique Viewers on a Given Day]

FTD: (First Time Deposit Conversion) – An acquisition model that is commonly used in the online gambling industry in order to measure conversion rates.   [Total Number of Unique Visitors ÷ Number of First Time Deposits]

K: (K-Factor) – A calculation for measuring the growth rate and virality of websites and apps. It can be simplified as invitations multiplied by conversions.   [Number of Invites Sent per Customer × Percentage of Conversions per Invite]   

LTV / CLV: (Lifetime Value / Customer Lifetime Value) – The predicted net profit attributed to the entire future relationship with a single customer. There are multiple ways to calculate LTV, but simply put, it is customer value multiplied by average customer lifespan.   [ARPU x (1 ÷ Churn Rate)] (Learn more)

MAU: (Monthly Active Users) – The number of users that interact with an app over the course of a given month.   [Sum Total of Unique Viewers on a Given Month]

RR: (Retention Rate) – The percentage of users who continue using an app over a given time period. The inverse of Churn Rate / Rate of Attrition.   [See here for calculation models]

ROAS: (Return on Ad Spend) – A metric used to calculate the efficacy of an advertising campaign. It is the amount of revenue a company receives for every dollar spent on an advertising source.   [Revenue ÷ Cost]

ROI: (Return on Investment) – The ratio of net profit to cost of investment; in other words, the pay-off for ad spend in user acquisition profits.   [(Total Ad Revenue – Total Ad Campaign Cost) ÷ Total Ad Campaign Cost]

Stakeholders

ADN: (Ad Network) – A brokerage platform that connects publishers with advertisers.          

AFN: (Affiliate Network) – An intermediary between publishers and merchant affiliate programs. Affiliate networks often manage tracking, reporting, and payment on behalf of affiliates. 

DSP: (Demand Side Platform) – A technology platform that advertisers use to automate the buying of ad space and the monitoring of campaigns.    

MB: (Media Buyer) – An individual or team responsible for the placements and price negotiation of advertisements.      

MMA: (Mobile Marketing Association) – An industry group that seeks to advance mobile marketing practices and technologies on a global level.   

MMP: (Mobile Measurement Partner / Attribution Partner) – A platform that provides deeper insights into mobile performance metrics through the collection, organization and standardization of app data.

MP: (Media Partner) – A media outlet or publisher connected to apps with advertising inventory.

PMP: (Private Marketplace) – An invite-only real-time marketplace where high-calibur publishers can offer their inventories to a select collection of reputable advertisers.

In other words, eCPA is a calculation that reveals what CPA would have been if actions had been bought instead of views, installs, etc.   [Total Ad Spend ÷ Total Number of Actions Taken]
CPC: (Cost per Click) – An ad KPI and pricing model that accounts for the price an advertiser pays for each click on an ad  [Cost to the Advertiser ÷ Number of Clicks]
CPI: (Cost per Install) – An ad KPI and pricing model that accounts for the price an advertiser pays only if an ad click results in an app install.   [Cost to the Advertiser ÷ Number of Installs (directly resulting from the ad campaign)]
eCPI: (effective Cost per Install) – An ad KPI and pricing model that measures the cost it takes to acquire a new install. Unlike CPI, eCPI factors in organic and viral installs.   [Total Ad Spend ÷ Total Number of Installs]
CPL: (Cost per Lead) – An ad KPI and pricing model that accounts for the price an advertiser pays for a relevant lead resulting from an ad campaign.   [Cost to the Advertiser ÷ Number of Campaign Leads]
CPM: (Cost per Mille) – An ad KPI and pricing model that accounts for the price an advertiser pays for one thousand views of an ad.   [Cost to the Advertiser ÷ Number of Campaign Impressions × 1000]
eCPM: (effective Cost per Mille) – An ad KPI and pricing calculation that measures the ad revenue generated per 1000 ad impressions. The main difference between CPM and eCPM is the data used to calculate it: eCPM is a way of calculating CPM for campaigns that did not use CPM as the buying method. In other words, eCPM is a calculation that reveals what CPM would have been if impressions had been bought instead of actions, installs, etc.   [Total Earnings from an Ad ÷ Total Impressions × 1000]
CPO: (Cost per Order / Cost per Purchase) – An ad KPI and pricing model that accounts for the price an advertiser pays for a successful order resulting from an ad campaign.   [Cost to the Advertiser ÷ Number of Campaign Orders]
CPS: (Cost per Subscription) – CPA specific for subscription services, where the action is defined as subscription of a user.   [Cost to the Advertiser ÷ Number of Campaign Subscriptions]
CPR: (Cost per Registration) – An ad KPI and pricing model that measures success based on the generation of new registrations.   [Cost to the Advertiser ÷ Number of Resulting Registrations]
CPV: (Cost per View / Cost per Visit) – Ad KPI and pricing model that accounts for the price an advertiser pays for interaction with the ad (e.g. click, play, expand). Particularly useful for campaigns utilising playable ads.   [Cost to the Advertiser ÷ Number of Campaign Views]
CR / CCR (Churn Rate / Customer Churn Rate) – The percentage of users whose business is lost (measured via inactivity or unsubscribes) during a given time period (i.e. the rate of attrition). The inverse of Retention Rate.   [Number of Lost Customers ÷ Total Number of Customers]
CR / CVR: (Conversion Rate) – The percentage of users who take a desired action after being exposed to an ad.   [Positive Conversions ÷ Clicks Received × 100]
CTIT: (Click to Install Time) – A type of distribution modelling used to analyze the ‘lag’ interval time-period between a click and its corresponding install. Useful for fraud detection.   [Installation Time – Ad Click Time]
CTR: (Click Through Rate) – The ratio of users who click on an advertised link to the users who view the page or app that has published the link.   [Total Ad Clicks ÷ Total Ad Impressions]
DAU: (Daily Active Users) – The number of users that interact with an app over the course of 24 hours.   [Sum Total of Unique Viewers on a Given Day]
FTD: (First Time Deposit Conversion) – An acquisition model that is commonly used in the online gambling industry in order to measure conversion rates.   [Total Number of Unique Visitors ÷ Number of First Time Deposits]
K: (K-Factor) – A calculation for measuring the growth rate and virality of websites and apps. It can be simplified as invitations multiplied by conversions.   [Number of Invites Sent per Customer × Percentage of Conversions per Invite]   
LTV / CLV: (Lifetime Value / Customer Lifetime Value) – The predicted net profit attributed to the entire future relationship with a single customer. There are multiple ways to calculate LTV, but simply put, it is customer value multiplied by average customer lifespan.   [ARPU x (1 ÷ Churn Rate)] (Learn more)
MAU: (Monthly Active Users) – The number of users that interact with an app over the course of a given month.   [Sum Total of Unique Viewers on a Given Month]
RR: (Retention Rate) – The percentage of users who continue using an app over a given time period. The inverse of Churn Rate / Rate of Attrition.   [See here for calculation models]
ROAS: (Return on Ad Spend) – A metric used to calculate the efficacy of an advertising campaign. It is the amount of revenue a company receives for every dollar spent on an advertising source.   [Revenue ÷ Cost]
ROI: (Return on Investment) – The ratio of net profit to cost of investment; in other words, the pay-off for ad spend in user acquisition profits.   [(Total Ad Revenue – Total Ad Campaign Cost) ÷ Total Ad Campaign Cost]

Stakeholders

ADN: (Ad Network) – A brokerage platform that connects publishers with advertisers.           
AFN: (Affiliate Network) – An intermediary between publishers and merchant affiliate programs. Affiliate networks often manage tracking, reporting, and payment on behalf of affiliates. 
DSP: (Demand Side Platform) – A technology platform that advertisers use to automate the buying of ad space and the monitoring of campaigns.     
MB: (Media Buyer) – An individual or team responsible for the placements and price negotiation of advertisements.       
MMA: (Mobile Marketing Association) – An industry group that seeks to advance mobile marketing practices and technologies on a global level.    
MMP: (Mobile Measurement Partner / Attribution Partner) – A platform that provides deeper insights into mobile performance metrics through the collection, organization and standardization of app data.
MP: (Media Partner) – A media outlet or publisher connected to apps with advertising inventory.
PMP: (Private Marketplace) – An invite-only real-time marketplace where high-calibur publishers can offer their inventories to a select collection of reputable advertisers.
